metadata.title: Feasibility of Pb phytoextraction using nano-materials assisted ryegrass: Results of a one-year field-scale experiment

Research article
Feasibility of Pb phytoextraction using nano-materials assisted ryegrass: Results of a one-year field-scale experiment
Shu-xuan Liang a, *, Yu Jin a, Wei Liu a, Xiliang Li b, Shi-gang Shen a, Ling Ding a
a College of Chemistry and Environmental Science, Hebei University, Baoding, 071002, PR China b Department of Preventive Medicine and Health Management, Hebei University, Baoding, 071000, PR China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 23 March 2016 Received in revised form 31 August 2016 Accepted 26 December 2016
Keywords: Nano-hydroxyapatite Lead Ryegrass Enhanced phytoremediation
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: liangsx168@126.com (S.-x. Liang).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvman.2016.12.064 0301-4797/© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
The effect of the combined application of nano-hydroxyapatite (NHAP) or nano-carbon black (NCB) on the phytoextraction of Pb by ryegrass was investigated as an enhanced remediation technique for soils by field-scale experiment. After the addition of 0.2% NHAP or NCB to the soil, temporal variation of the uptake of Pb in aboveground parts and roots were observed. Ryegrass shoot concentrations of Pb were lower with nano-materials application than without nano-materials for the first month. However, the shoot concentrations of Pb were significantly increased with nano-materials application, in particular NHAP groups. The ryegrass root concentrations of Pb were lower with nano-materials application for the first month. These results indicated that nano-materials had significant effects on stabilization of lead, especially at the beginning of the experiment. Along with the experimental proceeding, phytotoxicity was alleviated after the incorporation of nano-materials. The ryegrass biomass was significantly higher with nano-materials application. Consequently, the Pb phytoextraction potential of ryegrass significantly increased with nano-materials application compared to the gounps without nano-materials application. The total removal rates of soil Pb were higher after combined application of NHAP than NCB. NHAP is more suitable than NCB for in-situ remediation of Pb-contaminated soils. The ryegrass translocation factor exhibited a marked increase with time. It was thought that the major role of NHP and NBA might be to alleviate the Pb phytotoxicity and increase biomass of plants.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Heavy metal (HM) contamination in soil has become a serious environmental problem in China, particularly following the rapid industrialization of the nation. Anthropogenic industrial operations are a major source of pollution, including HM contamination. HMs have accumulated in soils through emissions from rapidly expanding industrial areas. These accumulations take the form of mine tailings, high industrial metal wastes, sewage sludge, wastewater irrigation, coal combustion residues, petrochemical spills, and atmospheric emissions (Wuana and Okieimen, 2011). The presence of HMs in a given ecosystem can lead to their accumulation in the food chain with negative effects on human health. HMs, such as lead (Pb), cadmium (Cd), arsenic (As) and mercury (Hg), are known to be toxic with the potential to cause dangerous diseases, including chronic poisoning (Ang et al., 2010). Compared
with organic pollutants, HMs cannot be decomposed through microbial action, and therefore their presence does not decrease with time, but instead, they can only be translocated within an environment. HMs will result in contamination even at relatively low level emissions because of their accumulation. HM contamination of farmland soil has become a serious concern in China because of their profound effect on food production, specifically on food quality and food safety of agricultural products. A number of remediation techniques have been investigated to remove HMs from soils. The overall objective of any soil remediation technology is to create a final solution resulting in the protection of human health and the environment. The remediation of HMs contaminated soils is still recognized nowadays to be one of the most difficult problems to be solved. Although many remediation technologies are still controversial in terms of their effectiveness and their impact on the deterioration of soil properties, a number of remediationmethods have been developed in an attempt to control soil contamination. These technologies can be classified within five categories of general approaches to remediation: isolation, immobilization, toxicity reduction, physical separation and extraction

(GWRTAC, 1997; Bolan et al., 2014). Several technologies exist for the remediation of HM-contaminated farmland soil. One or more of these approaches are often combined for more cost-effective treatment. Phytoremediation is an innovative use of green plants to extract, adsorb, or detoxify pollutants. It has been intensively studied due to its effectiveness, non-intrusiveness and low cost as an environmentally harmonious and widely accepted remediation technique for polluted soils (Singh et al., 2010; Garbisu et al., 2002; Nunez-Lopez et al., 2008). Nevertheless, phytoremediation has the disadvantage that it takes longer to implement compared with other treatments. For this reason the development of economically feasible remediation techniques represent a very interesting technological and scientific issue.
Lead is one of the most toxic HMs to organisms in the environment. It accumulates in the organs of the body (i.e., brain, kidneys), which may cause to serious injury to them, including the kidneys, where it results in a condition known as plumbism. Lead can also affect the nervous system and red blood cells, and can even cause death. Children exposed to lead are at a substantially greater risk for impaired development, a shortened attention span, hyperactivity, and mental disorders. With the rapid development in industrialization and urbanization, lead contaminated soil has become an increasingly serious problem, which can be directly attributed to atmospheric deposition, precipitation and other sources (Perry et al., 2012). Studies have shown that plants do not take up large quantities of lead found in the soil. Thus, it has been generally considered safe to use garden produce grown in soils with total lead levels of less than 300 mg/kg (Wuana and Okieimen, 2011). These findings indicate that lead does not readily accumulate in plants. In order to reduce the adverse impact of widespread Pb pollution, a growing number of studies have researched plants subject to different types of stabilization or extraction, in which the phytoextraction method has been demonstrated to be the most effective. Certain plant species can take up Pb and concentrate it in their harvestable plant parts. Indian mustard (Brassica juncea), alfalfa (Medicago sativa), cabbage (Brassicaoleraceavar.capitata), tall fescue (Festuca arundinacea), sargent juniper (Selaginella pulvinat), and poplar trees (Populus alba) have been used at various contaminated sites to extract lead from the soil in order to reduce lead contamination (Lambert et al., 1997; Wu et al., 2004). Ryegrass was used as a model plant due to its rapid growth, tolerance to various environments and soil types, and its common use in phytoremediation studies (Arienzo et al., 2004; Duo et al., 2005).
Nano-materials with large surface areas and excellent optical properties have been widely used to improve the environment. Nano-carbon black (NCB) is the product of biomass pyrolysis under minimal oxygen supply. Its high biocarbon content and its chemical stability in soil have encouraged experimentation on its potential use for long-term carbon sequestration (David et al., 2013). It has also been shown that the application of biochar to soils rapidly increases the soil fertility and, in turn, plant growth by supplying and retaining nutrients while improving soil physical and biological properties (Uzoma et al., 2011). Nano-hydroxyapatite (NHAP) can be used for HM contaminated soil in natural settings because it is a natural mineralized calcium apatite and is biocompatible; furthermore, it is readily available and inexpensive. Nano-materials can adsorb and fix lead in soils, which acts to reduce lead and its compounds in the environment by reducing their mobility. Over the years, many researchers have explored using new synthetic methods for the preparation and modification of nano-materials to promote their widespread use in pollution treatment (He et al., 2013; Ramesh et al., 2013).
The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of NHAP and NCB soil application for enhancing the phytoextraction of Pb from contaminated soils when using ryegrass (Lolium perenne L.). The
effect of NHAP and NCBwith ryegrass on the potential to remediate Pb-contaminated soils was determined by the Pb concentrations in different plant parts, the bioaccumulation and translocation factors of the plants, and the changes in the Pb content of rhizosphere soils. To carry out the study of the effect of the nano-materials on Pb remediation using ryegrass, the ryegrass treatments were established in pots indoors and then transferred to the field for the experiment.

sections.heading: 2.1. Site description and soil characteristics
sections.text: An experimental phytoextraction plot (16 m 4 m) was established on an artificial soil simulating Pb-contaminated soil of northern China. The soil was treated with 0.15 g/kg nitrogen (N), 0.075 g/kg phosphorus (P), and 0.15 g/kg potassium (K) once it was water permeable soft after half a month. Next, the physicochemical properties of the soil were analyzed at six randomly selected points using standard methods. The basic physicochemical properties of the soil are listed in Table 1. For the treatments where Pb was applied, lead nitrate (Pb(NO3)2) salt was used at a concentration of 1200 mg/kg of soil. The soil treatments were thoroughly mixed and later stabilized under natural conditions for a month to yield a homogeneous composite soil for use as the growth medium.

sections.heading: 2.2. Experimental design
sections.text:
The experimental design comprised 15 randomly selected field plots corresponding with five treatments and three replicates for each treatment. Each plot area was 1.8 1.8 m2 and protection line for each plot was 20 cm wide. NHAP and NCB were added to 0.2% soil weight (Soil thickness was 20 cm). The distribution of experimental plots is shown in Fig. 1.
Ryegrass seeds each weighing 70 g were sprayed over the plots and germinated 5 days later. Surface soil samples were collected after 1, 1.5, 2, 3 and 12 months. Three randomly selected samples were collected for treatment in which one was collected from each replicate.

sections.heading: 2.3. Extraction of plant and soil samples for Pb
sections.text: Harvested ryegrass samples were cleanedwith ultra-purewater, and shoots and roots were cut by ceramic scissors, weighed, and then dried for 30 min at 105 C and then at 70 C until constant weight was achieved. The shattered plant samples were then digested in a microwave oven using nitric acid-hydrogen peroxide. The soil samples were collected from the plots after the plant harvesting, air-dried at room temperature, and passed through a 2 mm sieve. Nitric acid, hydrogen peroxide, and hydrofluoric acid were used to digest the soil samples. The total Pb in the plant samples was determined using a graphite furnace atomic absorption spectrophotometer (TAS-990), whereas the total Pb in the soil samples was determined using a flame atomic absorption spectrophotometer (AA-6800).

sections.heading: 2.4. Data analysis
sections.text:
The accumulation of HMs in plants can be assessed by three factors: bioaccumulation coefficient (BAC), bioconcentration factor (BCF) and translocation factor (TF).
The BAC and BCF provide an index of the ability of the shoots and roots to accumulate the metal with respect to the metal concentration in the soil. The BAC and BCF are calculated respectively as the ratio of the trace element concentration in shoots and roots of plants at harvest to the concentration of the element in the external environment, such as soil (Putwattana et al., 2015). The TF is calculated as the ratio of the element concentration in shoots to roots, and indicates the ability of a plant to translocate metals upward from its roots to its shoots (Roongtanakiat, 2009).
BAC ¼ Concentration of metal in shoots ðmg=kgÞ Concentration of metal in soil ðmg=kgÞ (1)
BCF ¼ Concentration of metal in roots ðmg=kgÞ Concentration of metal in soil ðmg=kgÞ (2)
TF ¼ Concentration of metal in shoots ðmg=kgÞ Concentration of metal in roots ðmg=kgÞ (3)
Plants are divided into four categories of trace metal accumulation according to the BAC value: BAC value < 0.01 categorizes a plant as non-accumulator, 0.01e0.1 as low accumulator, 0.1e1.0 as moderate accumulator, and 1.0e10.0 as high accumulator (Sekabira et al., 2011). Plants with different BCF values are categorized as excluder, accumulator and hyperaccumulator when BCF values are <1.0, 1.0e10.0 and > 10.0, respectively (Ma et al., 2001). TF > 1 represent that translocation of metals effectively was made to the shoot from root (Fayiga and Ma, 2006).

sections.heading: 3.1. Biomass of ryegrass
sections.text:
In this study, ryegrass successfully germinated and grew. At the beginning of the experiment, the growth of ryegrass was weak. After adding the nano-materials, however, the ryegrass biomass increased significantly, especially for the NHAP combined ryegrass treatment. This finding may be due to NHAP fixation of Pb, which resulting the phytotoxicity of Pb was alleviated. And for another reason, NHAP of phosphorus containing materials acted to increase the amount of the nutrient phosphorus in the soil. The addition of phosphate as a nutritional supplement can promote the growth of the ryegrass (Ma et al., 1995; Sharma et al., 2007). As the
experiment progressed, the ryegrass biomass increased in the NCB combined ryegrass treatment, and in time showed no statistically significant difference in biomass when compared to with the NHAP combined ryegrass treatment.
After one year of the experiment, ryegrass in all treatment groups had grown faster than in the control groups. Therefore, the tested nano-materials can effectively reduce the toxic effects of Pbcontaminated soil on ryegrass. From these results, it could deduced that ryegrass was effectively used to fix Pb-contaminated soil.

sections.heading: 3.2. Pb bioavailability
sections.text:
Ryegrass has been recommended as a valuable tool for bioavailability assessment (Lambrechts et al., 2011). Among bioindicator plants used to monitor trace metals and with the capacity to accumulate them, ryegrass is frequently selected because of its high capacity for accumulation which makes its tolerant in general to HMs (Houben and Sonnet, 2012). Therefore, in this study, metal concentrations in ryegrass shoots were considered an indicator of the metal bioavailability in soils. Temporal variation of the uptake of Pb had been conducted by determination of Pb concentrations in aboveground parts (shoots) and roots in plants. The results are shown in Fig. 2.
Fig. 2 shows that Pb was detected in all ryegrass plant parts. In the ryegrass shoots with nano-material application treatments, the uptake of Pb by the plant increased with an increase in the Pb soil concentration and the amount of time of the experiment, whereas the results were opposite in the ryegrass only treatment. Lead concentrations in shoots gradually decreased from 750.93 to 163.92 mg/kg in the ryegrass only treatment, and the highest Pb concentrationwas observed in the first month. Lead concentrations in the ryegrass only treatment decreased as the ryegrass grew; however, this relationship may have been stronger if plant nutrients had been added after the addition of the Pb. Once ryegrass seedlings were 1.5 months old, the Pb content in the shoots in the nano-materials treatments was higher than those in the ryegrass only treatment. The accumulation ability was gradually enhanced in the presence of NHAP and NCB after 1.5 months.
Fig. 2 also shows roots that the highest Pb concentrations in roots were found in the groups without NHAP and NCB at the beginning of the month and a half. This result was largely explained by the effect of the nano-materials in reducing the activity of metal
ions in the soil, thereby reducing the absorptive capacity of the roots (Boisson et al., 1999). As the experiment progressed to the third month, the Pb content in roots gradually increased.
From the results of Fig. 2, the phytoextraction of Pb by future ryegrass harvest decreased in the order: ryegrass þ NHAP > ryegrass þ NCB > ryegrass. In general, in terms of ryegrass biomass and the accumulation of Pb in the soil, the best treatment was that with the NHAP application.

sections.heading: 3.3. Removal rates of Pb in soil
sections.text:
The ryegrass and the nano-materials had a remedial effect on Pb contaminated soil (Fig. 3).
The Pb removal rate from the soil of the ryegrass only group ranged from 16.74% to 31.76%. This was the minimum range among the three groups. The remediation efficiency in the ryegrass was more than 30.00% after one month of adding NHAP to the soil; therefore, NHAP was considered to be a good nano-material for phytoremediation in a short time frame. After three months, the NHAP and ryegrass combination treatment was the most effective because the removal rate of Pb from the soil reached 44.39% and increased to 46.55% after one year.
The addition of nano-materials increased the phytoremediation of Pb as a result of the passivation effect on Pb in the soil; specifically, the materials induced plant precipitation and adsorption after a stable complex was formed (Cui et al., 2014).
3.4. Bioaccumulation coefficient (BAC), bioconcentration factor and translocation factors for Pb
Fig. 4 represents the variation in the BAC of ryegrass (the Pb ratio between shoots and soil) after one-year treatments. Ryegrass plants grown in different treated soil were screened, BACs for Pb were less than 1.0 for ryegrass without nano-materials, suggesting that ryegrass was categorized as moderate accumulator. In the groups with NHAP and NCB, the BACs gradually increased with phytoremediation time, which was contrary to the changing law of the treatment without nano-materials. The treatments of ryegrass þ NHAP after one and half months and ryegrass þ NCB at one year showed BACs >1. The highest BAC for Pb (BAC ¼ 1.55) was obtained for ryegrass þ NHAP treatment. BAC values were greater than one for Pb respectively accumulated Pb in stems and leaves
that are harvestable and with high biomass. This is a vital characteristic for phytoextraction. The ryegrass plants can form a dense mat on the soil surface and are cosmopolitan, so it could accumulate Pb through vegetative growth and seedlings. Hence, nanomaterials assisted ryegrass could be labelled as high accumulators for Pb and potential plant specie for phytoextraction.
The BCF values (the Pb ratio between roots and soil) for ryegrass are given in Fig. 5. Most of BCFs were >1.0 with the exception of the treatments at one year. In general, the BCF value was >1.0, indicating the roots could accumulate Pb in the soil. The highest BCF for Pb (2.45) was found in ryegrass plants grown in control soil while those of nano-materials spiked soil plants had the lower BCF for Pb. Lead is largely immobile in soils and its extraction is limited by solubility and diffusion through root surface (Cataldo andWildung, 1978). Pb could be absorbed from soils by the roots of ryegrass. In addition BCF values in all of the treatments were gradually decreased with the time and eventually lower than 1.0 after oneyear growth of ryegrass, suggesting that too long growth period is detrimental to absorption of Pb in the roots.
The TF has been defined as the concentration of Pb in the plant aerial parts divided by the concentration of the Pb in plant roots. The ratio can be used to evaluate the translocation effects within ryegrass. The comparisons of the TF of the different treatments are shown in Fig. 6.
The ryegrass TF ratio varied between 0.16 and 1.66. All of the TF values were less than 1 in single ryegrass treatment, which signified that the plant was difficult effectively translocate Pb from roots to the shoots. Therefore, in general, there was only minimal translocation of Pb from the roots to the above ground plant parts. With the combination with nano-materials, TFs were increased dramatically. These results further illustrated that nano-materials could effectively promote the translocation of Pb from roots to shoots in ryegrass plants.
In Fig. 6, it can also be observed that the TF values of the experimental groups without nano-material application decreased with time. This finding may be caused by a saturation of the metal uptake or root to shoot transport mechanisms under conditions of high internal metal concentrations. Several reports also note that Pb is not easily translocated within plant tissues, most likely due to the high toxicity of Pb (Liu et al., 2003; Yoon et al., 2006). After the nano-materials were added, the TF values increased with time and the NHAP treatment showed a TF > 1.0 late in the experiment.
BAC, BCF and TF values greater than 1 had been used to assess the potential of plant species for phytoextraction and phytostabilization. Additionally, based on BACs, BCFs and TFs values, ryegrass has the potential for phytostabilization and phytoextraction of Pb from polluted soils, although it was not identified as Pb hyperaccumulator. However, ryegrass after the incorporation of nanomaterials had BCFs, BACs or TFs greater than 1 and was most effective in taking up Pb.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Plants accumulate Pb and distribute it in plant parts that are harvestable. A phytoremediation field experiment using nanomaterials and ryegrass was performed. Study results showed that ryegrass can be recommended as plants for phytoremediation of lead-contaminated soil. The plant species are ubiquitous, cosmopolitan and have relatively high biomass. The Pb phytoextraction potential by ryegrass significantly increased with NHAP application compared with the control and NCB application. The combined effects of a 0.2% NHAP soil application with ryegrass, can be effective to treat high concentrations of Pb in the soil.
The results shows that the phytoremediation effect of soil Pb in soil by NHAP combined with ryegrass can be achieved in the short term. Repeat harvest and testing of the ryegrass showed that the phytoremediation by ryegrass of Pb polluted soil was effective. Nano-materials combined with ryegrass assisted phytoextration, therefore, this method can be a green alternative to conventional
costly and environmentally unfriendly physical-chemical technologies.

Among bioindicator plants used to monitor trace metals and with the capacity to accumulate them, ryegrass is frequently selected because of its high capacity for accumulation which makes its tolerant in general to HMs (Houben and Sonnet, 2012).

metadata.abstractText: The effect of the combined application of nano-hydroxyapatite (NHAP) or nano-carbon black (NCB) on the phytoextraction of Pb by ryegrass was investigated as an enhanced remediation technique for soils by field-scale experiment. After the addition of 0.2% NHAP or NCB to the soil, temporal variation of the uptake of Pb in aboveground parts and roots were observed. Ryegrass shoot concentrations of Pb were lower with nano-materials application than without nano-materials for the first month. However, the shoot concentrations of Pb were significantly increased with nano-materials application, in particular NHAP groups. The ryegrass root concentrations of Pb were lower with nano-materials application for the first month. These results indicated that nano-materials had significant effects on stabilization of lead, especially at the beginning of the experiment. Along with the experimental proceeding, phytotoxicity was alleviated after the incorporation of nano-materials. The ryegrass biomass was significantly higher with nano-materials application. Consequently, the Pb phytoextraction potential of ryegrass significantly increased with nano-materials application compared to the gounps without nano-materials application. The total removal rates of soil Pb were higher after combined application of NHAP than NCB. NHAP is more suitable than NCB for in-situ remediation of Pb-contaminated soils. The ryegrass translocation factor exhibited a marked increase with time. It was thought that the major role of NHP and NBA might be to alleviate the Pb phytotoxicity and increase biomass of plants. © 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
